comments:
Hi,
I just restarted the workspace and it gave some error about not being able
to restore appearance settings.  I didn't note it down, or think it
important.

Suddenly it has over 6000 errors (previously none).

Basically, it doesn't recognise any plug-in dependencies in any projects.
It did before restarting.
They are still listed in the plugin.xml's, but the errors are as if they
weren't.

I have tried rebuilding the workspace and deleting and adding the
dependencies, but it makes no difference. Still all the errors.

Before I restarted, it was working, but running slowly and the memory 
footprint was getting bigger (about 130Mb).  After it was down to 30Mb.
It started rebuilding as I shut down.  It is possible it didn't finish.

I am using Eclipse 3.1 with Sun J2SE 1.5

Thanks
Roger
Is there anything of note in the log?  Passing on to PDE...

Go to the Plugin Development > Target Platform preference page.  Do you see 
plugins there?

Hi,
Thanks for getting on this so quickly.

The log file shows two out of memory/Java heap errors in the last hour before 
the fateful restart.  I was using Eclipse continually over this time.

There is an extract from the log below.

Surprising, because I thought that I had increased the memory with -Xmx500M on 
the command line for starting Eclipse and it never got anywhere near that.
The PC has 1GB of RAM and nothing much else was running (maybe Windows 
Explorer and Internet Explorer) occasionally.

The Target Platform Preferences still list the standard plug-ins which it 
cannot find as dependencies (e.g. JFace).

Thanks again
Roger

Here is the .log file extract...

what do you mean "plugin dependencies are not recongized"? If you expand 
the "Plug-in Dependencies" node under any of your Java projects, is it empty 
or does it reference JARs?

The projects seem to not compile because of an out of memory error, so I 
predict it's the latter.

Your prediction is correct.

By "dependencies not recognised", I mean the compiler errors relate to plug-
ins that are shown in the dependencies sheet on plugin.xml, but yes the 
dependencies are shown, both in plugin.xml and under each project.
For instance, many of the errors are that classes like Shell or Display cannot 
be resolved, even though JFace (and so implicitly SWT) are shown in 
dependencies.

Memory is certainly part of the problem, but not all of it.

I have now set the Eclipse start-up command line to end with
-vmargs -Xms300M -Xmx500M
which does seem to allocate 300Mb of memory (i.e. Task Manager PF usage goes 
up by >300Mb), but not change the situation (i.e. Rebuilding changes nothing).
javaw.exe is using 90Mb according to Task Manager.

If I import the standard plug-ins such as swt and jface they have errors too, 
even if I import them into an empty workspace, so it must be more than just 
the memory.  Although it might be a memory-caused corruption.
It would be nice if Eclipse could notify the user of memory problems - perhaps 
an enhancement.

The errors for org.eclipse.swt (imported as binary with linked content) for 
example are:

The project was not built since it depends on org.eclipse.swt, which has build 
path errors
Required library cannot denote external 
folder 'C:\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.swt_3.1.0' for project org.eclipse.swt
The project cannot be built until build path errors are resolved.

I have tried some other things in the meantime, with no success:
1. Copying the workspace to another computer and running the same version of 
Eclipse.
This does not give errors for SWT etc., but does for my plug-ins.
2. Deleting all of .metadata in the workspace, then importing one of the plug-
in projects as an existing project.
No improvement. It still can't find Display or Shell.

In view of 1. I will reinstall Eclipse in case the standard plug-ins are 
corrupted, but don't expect this to solve the problem entirely.

Thanks
Roger

Note that the code for swt in the org.eclipse.swt.win32 fragment, not the 
plugin itself.  Make sure you also import the fragment when you import the 
plugin.

This ought to solve your problem.

Hi Wassim,
Now it works again.
The missing links were the fragments point and that it had converted many 
import statements to identically-named, but wrong classes - e.g. 
java.awt.Color instead of the SWT Color.

So I went through the classes with errors, deleted the imports and did 
Ctrl+Shift+O a lot.

That resolves it as far as my workspace is concerned.
Whether a friendlier behaviour with memory errors is a practical enhancement, 
I leave up to you.

Thanks for your help
Roger

great.  closing.

Reporting of Out of memory errors is handled at the Platform level.
